entities.name: time zones
entities.description: Time zones are regions of the Earth that have adopted the same standard time, usually referred to by the number of hours they are offset from Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). They play a crucial role in organizing activities on a global scale and ensuring coordination across vast distances.

attributes.Purpose: To standardize time measurement and synchronize activities across vast distances

entities.name: global trade
entities.description: Global trade refers to the exchange of goods and services between countries, facilitating economic growth and development.

attributes.Impact on Time Zones: The expansion of global trade contributed to the need for a standardized system of time zones.

entities.name: transportation networks
entities.description: Transportation networks are systems of routes and infrastructure that facilitate the movement of people, goods, and services across various distances.

entities.name: Trains
entities.description: Trains are a mode of transportation that run on tracks and are used for both passenger and freight transport.

entities.name: standard time
entities.description: Standard time refers to the uniform system of time used within a specific region or country, typically based on time zones. It was introduced to synchronize schedules and reduce confusion caused by local solar times.

attributes.Purpose: To synchronize schedules and reduce confusion caused by local solar times

entities.name: mid-19th century
entities.description: The mid-19th century refers to the period from approximately 1850 to 1870.

entities.name: town or city
entities.description: A town or city is a human settlement that is larger than a village and smaller than a metropolis. In the context of time zones, each town or city would set its own time based on the local position of the sun before the standardization of time.

attributes.Size: Larger than a village, smaller than a metropolis

entities.name: sun
entities.description: The sun is the star at the center of the Solar System, providing light and energy to Earth.

attributes.Role in Time Measurement: Used for local solar time before standardized time zones

entities.name: British railway companies
entities.description: The British railway companies were responsible for the operation and management of railways in Britain during the 19th century. They played a crucial role in the development of standardized timekeeping practices.

entities.name: Sir Sandford Fleming
entities.description: Sir Sandford Fleming was a Canadian engineer who proposed the concept of time zones in the late 19th century.

entities.name: Canadian engineer
entities.description: A Canadian engineer who proposed the concept of time zones in the late 19th century.

entities.name: 19th century
entities.description: The 19th century spans from the year 1801 to 1900. It was a period marked by significant technological, industrial, and social changes.

entities.name: International Meridian Conference
entities.description: The International Meridian Conference was held in Washington, D.C. in 1884 to standardize time zones and adopt a system based on Greenwich Mean Time (GMT).
The year 1884 was significant for the establishment of standard time zones based on Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) at the International Meridian Conference held in Washington, D.C.

entities.name: Greenwich Mean Time (GMT)
entities.description: Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) is a time standard based on the mean solar time at the Royal Observatory in Greenwich, London. It serves as the reference point for coordinating time across the globe.

entities.name: Greenwich Meridian
entities.description: The Greenwich Meridian, also known as the Prime Meridian, is a line of longitude that serves as the reference point for measuring time zones and coordinates around the world. It passes through the Royal Observatory in Greenwich, London.

entities.name: London
entities.description: London, the capital of England and the United Kingdom, is one of the world"s leading cities known for its history, culture, and global influence.

entities.name: Prime Meridian
entities.description: The Prime Meridian, also known as the Greenwich Meridian, is a line of longitude that serves as the reference point for measuring time zones and coordinates around the world.

entities.name: United States
entities.description: The United States of America (USA) is a federal republic composed of 50 states, a federal district, five major self-governing territories, and various possessions. It is one of the world"s most influential countries in terms of economic, political, and cultural impact.

entities.name: Eastern
entities.description: The Eastern Time Zone is one of the four time zones in the United States, covering a significant portion of the eastern part of the country.

attributes.Region Covered: Eastern Part of the United States

entities.name: Central
entities.description: The Central Time Zone is one of the four time zones in the United States, alongside Eastern, Mountain, and Pacific.

entities.name: Mountain
entities.description: The Mountain Time Zone is one of the four time zones in the United States, along with Eastern, Central, and Pacific.

entities.name: Pacific
entities.description: The Pacific Time Zone is one of the four time zones in the United States, covering parts of the western coast and inland areas.

entities.name: Other countries
entities.description: A group of countries that followed the adoption of standard time zones and adjusted their timekeeping practices to align with the new system.

attributes.Time Keeping Practices: Adjusted to align with standard time zones

entities.name: new standard
entities.description: The new standard refers to the standardized timekeeping system adopted after the International Meridian Conference, which facilitated global communication and coordination.

entities.name: Daylight Saving Time (DST)
entities.description: Daylight Saving Time (DST) is the practice of advancing clocks by one hour during the warmer months to extend daylight hours in the evening.

attributes.Purpose: To extend daylight hours in the evening

entities.name: 20th century
entities.description: The 20th century spans from the year 1901 to 2000 and is marked by significant technological, social, and cultural advancements.

entities.name: World War I
entities.description: World War I, also known as the Great War, was a global conflict that lasted from 1914 to 1918. It involved many of the world"s great powers and resulted in significant political, economic, and social changes.

entities.name: technology
entities.description: Technology encompasses the tools, methods, and processes used to solve problems and improve human life. It includes a wide range of innovations from simple tools to complex systems.

attributes.Role in Communication: Enables instant communication and real-time collaboration across vast distances
attributes.Impact on Time Coordination: Has made coordinating time across different time zones easier than ever

entities.name: communication
entities.description: Communication refers to the exchange of information or news among people through speaking, writing, or using some other medium.

entities.name: Countries around the world
entities.description: Various countries that adopted and implemented the standardized system of time zones following the International Meridian Conference.

entities.name: global telecommunications networks
entities.description: Global telecommunications networks enable instant communication and real-time collaboration across vast distances.

entities.name: standard time zones
entities.description: Standard time zones are a system of timekeeping based on Greenwich Mean Time (GMT), adopted to facilitate global communication and coordination.

entities.name: local time systems
entities.description: Local time systems are based on the solar time at a specific location, which can vary significantly across different regions.

entities.name: Local Time
entities.description: Local time is a system where each town or region sets its own time based on the position of the sun.

entities.name: Railway Time
entities.description: Railway Time is a standardized time system adopted by British railway companies in 1847.

entities.name: Time Zone System
entities.description: The time zone system is a global standard for dividing the Earth into regions with uniform time.

entities.name: British Railway Companies
entities.description: The British railway companies were among the first to adopt standard time in 1847 for their schedules, known as Railway Time.

entities.name: Local Solar Time
entities.description: Local solar time is based on the position of the sun in the sky and varies from place to place.

entities.name: Countries Around the World
entities.description: Following the adoption of standard time zones at the International Meridian Conference, countries around the world began to implement the new system.

entities.name: Standardized Timekeeping on a Regional Level
entities.description: The adoption of standard time marked the beginning of standardized timekeeping on a regional level.

entities.name: Standard Time
entities.description: Standard time is a system of dividing the world into 24 time zones, each generally corresponding to one hour of longitude.

entities.name: Standard Time Zones
entities.description: A system of standard time zones based on Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) was adopted at the International Meridian Conference in 1884.

entities.name: Country
entities.description: A country is a geographical region that has a defined territory and a permanent population, usually with a government and sovereignty over the land.

entities.name: Time Zone
entities.description: A time zone is a region that observes a uniform standard time for legal, commercial, and social purposes.

entities.name: local solar time
entities.description: Local solar time is a method of measuring time based on the position of the sun in the sky.

entities.name: natural daylight
entities.description: Natural daylight is the light provided by the sun during the day.

entities.name: Trains and Telegraphs
entities.description: Technologies that played a significant role in highlighting the need for standardized timekeeping.

entities.name: Other Countries
entities.description: Countries that adopted similar standardized timekeeping practices after Britain.

entities.name: Time Zones
entities.description: The concept of time zones as we know them today was first proposed by Sir Sandford Fleming in the late 19th century. It involves dividing the world into 24 time zones, each one representing a one-hour difference in mean solar time.

entities.name: 24 Time Zones
entities.description: Fleming suggested dividing the world into 24 time zones, each one representing a one-hour difference in mean solar time.

entities.name: Global Timekeeping Practices
entities.description: The concept of time zones proposed by Sir Sandford Fleming influenced global timekeeping practices, leading to the standardization of time across different regions.

entities.name: Global Communication
entities.description: The field that deals with the exchange of information across different regions and countries.

entities.name: Local Time Usage
entities.description: Using local time across long distances was inefficient, especially for trains and telegraphs.

entities.name: Washington, D.C.
entities.description: The capital city of the United States, located along the Potomac River.

entities.name: Standard Time Zones Based on GMT
entities.description: A system of standard time zones based on Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) was adopted to address the inefficiencies of using local time across long distances.

entities.name: Royal Observatory
entities.description: The Royal Observatory is located in Greenwich, London, and it plays a significant role in the history of navigation and timekeeping.

entities.name: United Kingdom
entities.description: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (UK) is a sovereign country located off the northwestern coast of continental Europe.

entities.name: Greenwich Observatory
entities.description: The Greenwich Observatory is a historic observatory located in London, England.

entities.name: Implementation of Standard Time Zones
entities.description: Following the conference, countries around the world began to implement the new system of standard time zones.

entities.name: Standardized Time Zones
entities.description: A standardized system of time zones was adopted to facilitate precise and consistent time measurement, enhancing global communication and coordination.

entities.name: Global Time Coordination
entities.description: Advances in technology and communication have made it easier to coordinate time across different time zones globally.

entities.name: Eastern Time Zone
entities.description: The Eastern Time Zone is one of the four time zones in the United States, located to the east of the Central Time Zone.

entities.name: Mountain Time Zone
entities.description: The Mountain Time Zone is one of the four time zones in the United States, located to the west of the Central Time Zone.

entities.name: Pacific Time Zone
entities.description: The Pacific Time Zone is one of the four time zones in the United States, located to the west of the Mountain Time Zone.

entities.name: Conference on Time Zones
entities.description: A conference that divided the world into 24 time zones, each spanning 15 degrees of longitude.

entities.name: Global Communication and Coordination
entities.description: Effective communication and coordination across different regions and time zones are essential for global operations.

entities.name: Many Countries
entities.description: A broad range of countries around the world.

entities.name: Early 20th Century
entities.description: The early part of the 20th century.

entities.name: Advances in Technology and Communication
entities.description: Significant advancements in technology and communication have made it easier to coordinate time across different time zones.

entities.name: Daylight Saving Time
entities.description: Daylight Saving Time (DST) is the practice of advancing clocks during summer months to make better use of natural daylight.

entities.name: Internet
entities.description: A global system of interconnected computer networks that use the Internet protocol suite (TCP/IP) to link devices worldwide.

entities.name: Global Telecommunications Networks
entities.description: A network of telecommunications systems that connect people and organizations around the world.

entities.name: Global Coordination
entities.description: Global coordination involves the synchronization of activities and efforts across different regions and time zones.

entities.name: Technology
entities.description: Technology encompasses the tools, methods, and processes used to create, develop, and improve products and services.

entities.name: Real-Time Collaboration
entities.description: Real-time collaboration involves multiple individuals working together on a project or task simultaneously.
